author: @bluestarcesium
comment: There are many people, who brought Nvidia on margins, and the stock watchers and options traders know when a stock is topping out, then, they sell the stock. Then, the short sellers start selling the stock short. This causes there to be more sellers than buyers, and the stock falls faster. Then, margin calls are made, which causes many more shares to hit the market. Soon, all the day traders are out, the people on margin are out, and the stock starts to bottom ten to fifteen percent below it‚Äôs high. The shares begin a bottoming process of consolidation, where large mutual funds, investors, and traders begin to accumulate some shares.

author: @bluemoon6559
comment: After GTC, the moat for Nvidia just got much much wider.  Nvidia is solving the tough issues with AI and Accelerated Computing.  No one else is talking about these things.  The competition is so behind that they are only focused on making a faster processor.  Nvidia revealed that the important considerations are energy usage and the TOC (total operating cost), not just faster processors.  You can have the fastest processor in the world, but if it burns 100MW to run it and requires humongous liquid nitrogen tanks to cool it, you will be out of business right away.  From the GTC, it shows Nvidia has figured out the sweet spot to operate their entire ecosystem and continues to optimize the hardware and software to squeeze out the most profit.  TOC is the bottom line and Nvidia is the only one talking about it in addition to all the innovations they have developed overcoming all the hardware and software issues.

author: @mikebuchanan7610
comment:
Not to derail, but Trump's argument about the Canadian border stretches the truth to put it mildly, and is not likely to have the result he intended. He used the IEEPA to get around his own trade agreement in order to impose tariffs, but less than 1% of illegals and fentanyl come from Canada. What emergency? The result of this is that Canadians have concluded that they cannot trust Trump, and that means not trusting America for at least the next four years. Hard to negotiate with people who do not trust you. He is, however, accomplishing something once thought to be impossible. Canada is now looking to remove provincial trade barriers. It is estimated that these barriers add up to the equivalent of a 21% tariff, and removing them will add roughly $200B to the economy. Canada is also looking to diversify trade, which may mean lost opportunity for the US in the future, and diminished influence, as the end goal would be to get into a position where this kind of leverage cannot be used again. Rather than making it the 51st state, he's making it more nationalistic.

I agree that this is largely unrelated, and thus it is a buying opportunity. I already have a large position in Nvidia, but added leaps at 100 and 105.

Thanks for a great point of View. I'd love for to hear your opinion of Sivers semiconductors. 

Sivers Semiconductors ‚Äì The Backbone of AI Connectivity
As AI scales, Nvidia‚Äôs GPUs demand high-speed, low-latency data transfer‚Äîand that‚Äôs where Sivers comes in. Their silicon photonics and mmWave solutions enable ultra-fast optical interconnects for AI data centers, making them a critical supplier in the AI infrastructure boom.

With a ‚Äúpicks and shovels‚Äù position in the AI race and potential ties to Nvidia‚Äôs growing ecosystem, Sivers is poised for exponential growth as demand for high-bandwidth connectivity surges.

That's my opinion and finding but I would like to hear what the professionals think. ü§î

author: @andikasapi9563
comment:
‚ÄúI hope Nvidia loses more money because they have done the worst marketing ever and provided almost no product. There has been a huge lack of stock, consequently disappointing all customers. What was the point of trying to get people hyped for the 50-series if there are no GPUs? I saw massive queues at the shops, with people camping overnight like Bear Grylls, wrapped in blankets just to survive the night.

It was the worst launch day I have ever experienced. I was personally disgusted to see stock issues making a comeback, reminiscent of post-WWII Eastern European communism. Instead of planning ahead to prevent these issues, they blamed the Chinese New Year‚Äîjust another excuse. We‚Äôre talking about a massive engineering company, yet their CEO, in his glittering new Las Vegas jacket, was busy showing off extreme graphics performance while customers struggled to get their hands on the product.

Something seems a little off to me. It feels like old-school dictator propaganda‚Äîhyping up a product with barely any stock, forcing desperate people to camp overnight just to get a tiny piece of the ridiculously rationed supply.‚Äù

author: @shwazine5358
comment: Yeah, the panic makes no sense to me. Assuming everything the Chinese said is true (historically speaking... doubtful), we should be able to easily replicate and improve upon it, especially since we have access to better processors than they do. America's AI industry isn't just going to go "Oh noes... we're done for!" and roll over. They're going to incorporate the efficiencies and improvements and make ours that much better. And the doom and gloomers who respond that China will just keep improving faster fail to understand one critical fact. This was a one shot deal by the Chinese. They did this by building off ChatGPT with restricted Nvidia GPUs and now they can't even get those anymore. There's really no way for them to progress further without access, which could mean war over Taiwan in 2027 (for why 2027, check out some military geopolitical channels). However, we have the trump card in that even if they were to take over Taiwan, we can cut them off from the raw materials needed. Almost all of the world's semiconductor grade supply of silicon is in the US. America is the linchpin of the AI age, and we'll either lead it or we'll cut the world off, and the sooner everyone realizes that the better. America's position in the world since WWII has always been a carrot first, stick if necessary approach because the carrot allows everyone to benefit. For the past 80 years, that's been about oil. America held its position in the world because it ensured global free trade with the base of that being the free transport of oil and gas. And our non-nuclear doomsday scenario was always that if the world turned against us, we'd become an island and starve out the rest of the world by destroying the free trade of oil and gas. A similar strategy applies to the AI age. We'll hold our position as the hub of AI for the benefit of the world, or the world won't have AI.

author: @The_Pair_Trader
comment: China's new AI model, DeepSeek, could have significant implications for Nvidia and AMD. As DeepSeek advances, it highlights the increasing demand for AI-driven hardware, positioning Nvidia and AMD as key players in this growing market. Nvidia, with its strong GPU presence, could benefit from further demand for its high-performance chips. On the other hand, AMD, while also strong in the semiconductor space, might face increased competition if China develops more localized alternatives. For investors, this could mean volatility or opportunity depending on how these companies respond to the evolving AI landscape.

Deep Seek is run on NVDA's H800, and older, less advanced chip that's not export-restricted, thus China or anyone can buy them, and we don't care... the H800 holds no valuable secrets. Thus, China, without access to the Blackwell, is nowhere near able to service the immensely complex platforms like Facebook, Instagram, Google Search, Google Cloud, MSFT Azure, AMZN AWS, etc, etc. Deep Seek is only able to "almost" match ChatGPT, a few AI graphics tools like ADBE's new photoshop functions, plus manage simple computer networks within offices in China. author: @garyk.nedrow8302
comment: The financial media is missing the mark on NVDA.  The stock has sold off since its last earnings announcement because it is fairly valued for now and the fast  money guys (FMG) are dumping shares of NVDA to chase the upward trend in financial and military defense stocks.  It is a simple rotation of speculators out of NVDA.  The speculative hysteria is over, but the reality remains that NVDA itself is a buy.  It made its 3rd quarter numbers and will continue to grow, at a slightly less meteoric pace, for the foreseeable future.  It is very likely, given its enormous cash position, that NVDA will soon become a much larger company (via acquisition or organic growth in new product lines) and generate even greater profits.  The tech revolution will be powered by NVDA for years to come.

author: @GeoEmertech
comment:
The market clearly over-reacts. They haven't even read the DeepSeek details. The "low cost" presented by DeepSeek was per one training run. But you need multiple runs to train an AI and this doesn't include the initial investment in the 50K H100 datacenter they used to train the AI. The savings come from using existing models to train new models. And this is an expected next step in the AI revolution that is known in tech circles for months. And many more steps like this will follow. Lower costs, better performance, more niche applications is the story of every new tech we invented. 

Long term, NVidia still wins. At the end of the AI revolution, the big money will be in inference compute, in AI usage. And as you said, the lower the entry level, the more applications you get. Remember the evolution of the computer itself. First we had those huge mainframes that only a handful companies could buy. Then we had the PC that anyone could buy. And now we have smart devices with more compute power than those initial PCs. Every step of this evolution created more demand, more money for the companies behind the push. But also heed the warning in this example: the companies that built the initial frameworks are not the ones building the current smart devices.

author: @I_Did_That_47
comment:
Things to keep in mind:
1. The low cost claimed for deepseek is dubious. The 6 million dollar cost they claim is just for training it, nothing else. And even that, I am skeptical of. The numbers are cooked to look good.
2. They are using high-end NVDA GPUs; they just cannot admit they are because they are not supposed to have them. So, of course, they are claiming they did this with low-end GPUs. 
3. This is China, they are known to lie and steal IP. They made this by scraping chat gpt. Most of the work was already done for them by other companies.
4. They did this using high end gpu's which they got thru a backdoor illegally, likely from Singapore, but they cannot admit that. I say that because:
5. Singapore is a tiny country with no AI companies or AI infrastructure, yet they bought $7.7 billion of high end gpu's from Nividia. Where do you think those ended up? 
6. Think of all the highly skilled engineers at Google, MS, and Meta. Do you really think they all missed some way to do this cheaply? If deepseek's supposed cost was real, one of these people would have found the way to do this sooner and either told their employer to save them money or left to start their own highly profitable start-up.
7. They claim they only used 2000 gpu's. It has been leaked/claimed that the real number was actually 50,000 gpu's. But again, they cannot admit that because they were not supposed to have them.

TLDR: This is an overreaction to dubious claims from a dubious country, which should be seen as a buying opportunity, IMHO.

author: @JulienBonin-i1c
comment:
Why would Nvidia's customer reduce spending? Microsoft isn't buying the hardware just for training expensive models. Think of all the other workloads that can/will be performed on this hardware. Any computationally intensive workload will be performed on blackwell chips as it will allow companies to decrease their costs. This included language models (training/inferencing), robotics, autonomous driving, data pipelines, other machine learning jobs, etc.

If the cost to train models is reduced drastically (let's say 100k) to train a ChatGPT level model, then more companies will be creating their own models (which is where we'll probably be in the future). 

If you listen to Jensen over the last 1-2 years, they are focused on brining down the cost of computation. Nvidia isn't worried about the cost to train these language models. In fact, they are anticipating this happening. So is all the hyper-scalers. Language models will be built by every company for their own specific use case. This has been the understanding for some time.

author: @cjhodges14
comment:
Is it just me, or are things not quite adding up? The more I've pondered this Deepseek situation since Saturday night, the more it feels like we're witnessing a standard correction for AI and data center stocks, which have seen massive gains over the last year and a half.

If the DeepSeek announcement was truly an existential threat to companies like Nvidia), why would Meta have announced on Friday a $65 billion investment in AI infrastructure for 2025? They obviously knew about the Deepseek announcement. And why did the Bank of China commit to spending $137 billion on AI infrastructure just a couple of days ago?

Did DeepSeek actually achieve a breakthrough in training large language models (LLMs)? It appears so, but I suspect they used many more GPUs than they're admitting. On the other hand if this  breakthrough is genuine, it's a boon for humanity and the world. Sure, some tech companies might need to pivot their strategies, but in five years, we might all be thankful for what they've uncovered. Rather than wasting time, money, and energy on training LLMs we can work on other things. 

As for my investments, I've got five years' worth of cash set aside as an emergency fund - my "break glass in case of emergency" money. Apart from that, I'm fully invested in stocks, so I can't really buy into this dip. But I'm not selling either. I'll just be patient and continue with my business as usual.

Have a nice day y'all.

author: @sonaldosui8154
comment:
I don't think the report issued by Deepseek is true and accurate. Since DeepSeek is still a private company that does not have an obligation to release a full company operation report to the public, there is a huge amount of data that is withheld from the public. According to Scale AI CEO and other relevant resources, DeepSeek is believed to obtain 50,000 H100 chips that are not told to the public. Moreover, the report from DeepSeek did not mention or include the spending of 50,000 units of H100 chips. The report only included a few older versions of NVDA chips. Deepseek will not release this information regardless of any public investigation due to the nature of H100 in possession being illegal for Chinese companies. And certain export restrictions/sanctions are in place against China. This explains why DeepSeek can't report full amount of spending, leading to a final report with fraction of the cost. 

Don't be surprised that China has a sufficient amount of H100, because there are existing path and route for China to obtain the H100 chips illegally from Southeast Asian nations.

author: @phvaessen
comment: During 60 years the law of Moore confirmed that performance was doubling exponentially every two years. Nobody would have said that the computers were too fast and Intel would become bankrupt by lack of demand. Nvidia improved the performance of the accelerated computing platform 1000x in 8 years, nobody then would believe Nvidia would stop selling its GPU's. AI's performance is growing 4 to 7 times faster than the law of Moore. DeepSeek is not a big surprise, it's the normal trend of law of exponential returns: the last performance improvement is based on the advancement of the previous generation.

author: @phvaessen
comment:
AI is the electricity of the future. Imagine someone in 1900 claiming that electricity was a bubble. Back then, most people could only envision it as a replacement for gas lamps ‚Äî few could imagine the vast array of applications that would follow. We're at a similar point today with AI.
The real impact of AI will come from practical implementations. Fully autonomous vehicles and humanoid robots are just early examples of physical AI, and they‚Äôre set to drive massive demand. But the biggest catalyst will be AI factories ‚Äî infrastructure purpose-built to generate intelligence. To put it in perspective: out of the $100 trillion global economy, electricity accounts for 3‚Äì5%, or $3‚Äì5 trillion annually (and closer to double that if you include the entire energy sector). That gives you a sense of the total addressable market (TAM) for AI infrastructure. That AI infrastructure is a platform composed of hardware (GPU, CPU, DPU, Network connectivity), Software, and domain expertise applications) which only Nvidia is able to deliver. And right now, Nvidia controls 90% of that emerging market.

In the race for the world‚Äôs most valuable resource, AI time cycle is increasingly important. I think of an AI time cycle as the time it takes from the day you decide you‚Äôre going to build an AI, to the time that you release it for public use. 

$NVDA not only offers the best products and services for AI creation, the also offer the best time cycle for AI on the planet. As an example, consider xAI and Grok3, announcement to release was 180 days. xAI used full Nvidia stacks (hardware, GPUs, software, networking and liquid cooling). xAI‚Äôs creation, Grok3, and the associated time cycle are unheard of, Grok3 is record breaking in intelligence, performance, and time cycle.

Regarding Deepseek, they basically leached / stole knowledge to make their R1 smarter. That‚Äôs how they saved money.

xAI is now moving from 200,000 $NVDA stacks towards 1,000,000 $NVDA stacks. I believe that at one million $NVDA stacks, xAI is going to create something the likes to which we‚Äôve never seen before. And at that level, it might just break Geoffrey Hinton‚Äôs model for distillation, meaning it might not be possible at that level. Sorry China.

OBTW LLMs are not the end-all, be-all of AI. We are just getting started. We got things like neurosymbolic stuff, liquid neural networks, multi-modal, autonomous agents, self-improvement and replication, and other undiscovered creations, concentrations and quantities.

author: @Vlad-qu5mt
comment:
DeepSeek‚Äôs impressive breakthroughs‚Äîeven when achieved through clever algorithmic optimizations‚Äîstill depend fundamentally on high‚Äêperformance Nvidia GPUs. For example, DeepSeek‚Äôs own V3 model was trained using a cluster of 2,048 Nvidia H800 GPUs, underscoring that even ‚Äúefficient‚Äù training methods cannot escape the need for powerful, purpose‚Äêbuilt hardware.

Moreover, as AI becomes increasingly critical to business operations, more companies are expected to invest in continuously training and retraining custom models to remain competitive. This trend only reinforces the long‚Äëterm demand for Nvidia‚Äôs advanced GPU technology. Their GPUs offer the performance, reliability, and ecosystem support (via CUDA, NVLink, and other proprietary innovations) that are essential for scaling up AI workloads‚Äîadvantages that are hard to replicate with alternative hardware.

In short, despite DeepSeek‚Äôs strides in reducing compute costs, the industry‚Äôs future remains tied to high‚Äëperformance GPUs. As more firms look to develop tailored AI solutions, Nvidia‚Äôs leadership in the AI accelerator space is set to continue driving robust demand.

REUTERS.COM
 
BUSINESSINSIDER.COM

author: @chriswinslow
comment: These people are driving me nuts with their shortsightedness and lack of knowledge of Large Langue Models. DeepSeek R1 was built on top of Metas Llama AND Qwen, which in turn needed lots and lots of data processing capabilities, so DeepSeek got a "piggyback" to where it is today, not to mention OpenAI openly said they have evidence that DeepSeek used ChatGPT to train the R1 model, which I would not put past them of doing. If Llama, Qwen and indeed ChatGPT stopped now so would DeepSeek and it would not advance more than what it currently is, as it would have nothing to piggyback off/leech off! Watching this reinforces my thoughts about how clueless analysts are especially when it comes to LLM's. If you feel DeepSeek's R1 is all we need in and the AI revolution only exists in businesses and done without without immense compute power, then sell all your shares at the next market open. But, if you think like me that AI will drive humanity in new and exciting directions for businesses and the public, then you need to not only keep but too add more shares like nVidia as the immense computing power needed to train more sophisticated LLM's will be needed and the demand will grow.

author: @albertofourie3294
comment:
Problem with Nvidia is that stellar quarterly results have become far too predictable if not boring. Guidance for an ensuing  quarter is always 5% higher which of course Nvidia always beat by a small margin. Blowout quarters (what the market wants) are a thing of the past due to supply constraints. Essentially, Nvidia is at capacity and can deliver no more, regardless of pent-up demand.
In short, Nvidia's growth has been stunted with their stock price following suit.

author: @phvaessen
comment:
microsoft speculation of TD Cowen, has been debunked by Microsoft in a press release reaffirming its spending target for the fiscal year ending in June.
amplifying debunked rumours (like deepseek which is in fact a tailwind for nvidia) and this one (what's the reason for canceling a lease (renewal before negotiation) , You need to be more critical and understand better the business of the companies you analyse, looking at the figures is not enough to give solid advice. Unless you're only short term focussed. 
Long term investment requires disregarding these rumours and market noise. If you understand the AI market you know the trend is not ending with LLM AI training, the race goes up to reach ASI, then AI inference is much bigger and follows the current AI training spending phase. Moreover Sovereign AI is just starting and will replace or supplement the hyperscalers. Omnivers and Cosmos allows physical AI to train, explore, simulate, experiment and optimise various physical sitations with virtual twins. This is not future or may be, it is currently being used by a lot of enterprises already, and it's a much bigger TAM for Nvidia than the current hyperscallers investments in AI.

author: @phvaessen
comment:
AI is the electricity of the future. Imagine someone in 1900 claiming that electricity was a bubble. Back then, most people could only envision it as a replacement for gas lamps ‚Äî few could imagine the vast array of applications that would follow. We're at a similar point today with AI.
The real impact of AI will come from practical implementations. Fully autonomous vehicles and humanoid robots are just early examples of physical AI, and they‚Äôre set to drive massive demand. But the biggest catalyst will be AI factories ‚Äî infrastructure purpose-built to generate intelligence.
To put it in perspective: out of the $100 trillion global economy, electricity accounts for 3‚Äì5%, or $3‚Äì5 trillion annually (and closer to double that if you include the entire energy sector). That gives you a sense of the total addressable market (TAM) for AI infrastructure.
And right now, Nvidia controls 90% of that emerging market.
You still want to sell your Nvidia ?

author: @huongnguyen9028
comment:
Big techs will be doomed if they keep using PCB (printed circuit board for semiconductor packaging)
Furthermore, there are obstacles to upgrading the HBM because of overheating. 
It means no further AI developments so long as there is none of Paradigm shift.
The only way for the big techs such as NVIDIA, BROADCOM, AMD, and so on to survive is to use glass substrate. 
Glass Substrate will dramatically solve the overheating and other constraints that PCB has had.
Absolics is the first company that makes the glass substrate mass productions.
korean company, philoptics,has the most advanced technology, TGV, which is the major part  of glass substrate.

However, the "dark cloud" hanging over NVIDIA is the fear that continuos advancement in approaches to  pre-training, post-training and inference will result in fewer chips being needed and sold by NVIDIA. Wall Street does not understand the "Jevons paradox" (i.e., making something more efficient can paradoxically lead to greater total consumption, not less.) and until they do or they are shown, NVIDIA will continued to be questioned and stock price will under perform its potential.

author: @HartJ-r9e
comment:
There are multiple methods for cooling these Nvdia chips .such as Air cooling, liquid cooling and hybrids between between air and liquid cooling . Liquid cooling can be done such methods as cool plate cooling ,which transfers heat from each chip in a rack via a refrigerant , then there is the total immersion method which uses a dielectric fluid to transfer heat from the chips . It is certainly conceivable that one of these cooling methods is proving to be less than capable of providing adequate cooling for these Blackwell chips ,versus the other available cooling methods . My initial suspicion is these might be the air cooling method ,which is the least efficient in transferring heat versus the liquid cooling methods ,with liquid being much more efficient vs air cooling via fans only . 
Just look at the cooling options offered via offered by SuperMicro ,Vertiv and Major Modine , and their various cooling methods that they respectively offer . By way of disclosure ,I am a shareholder in Vertiv and Major Modine .

author: @phvaessen
comment:
microsoft speculation of TD Cowen, has been debunked by Microsoft in a press release reaffirming its spending target for the fiscal year ending in June.
amplifying debunked rumours (like deepseek which is in fact a tailwind for nvidia) and this one (what's the reason for canceling a lease (renewal before negotiation) , You need to be more critical and understand better the business of the companies you analyse, looking at the figures is not enough to give solid advice. Unless you're only short term focussed. 
Long term investment requires disregarding these rumours and market noise. If you understand the AI market you know the trend is not ending with LLM AI training, the race goes up to reach ASI, then AI inference is much bigger and follows the current AI training spending phase. Moreover Sovereign AI is just starting and will replace or supplement the hyperscalers. Omnivers and Cosmos allows physical AI to train, explore, simulate, experiment and optimise various physical sitations with virtual twins. This is not future or may be, it is currently being used by a lot of enterprises already, and it's a much bigger TAM for Nvidia than the current hyperscallers investments in AI.

If it falls 10% after earnings from the 127ish level (as other analysts suggest) then NVDA will be in the 114ish zone tomorrow. If NVDA closes today at the 124ish level then +10% would be 136ish or 111ish on a 10% decline after earnings. So in both cases the best case scenario for the highs after earnings both fall below the 142-144 channel of resistance. NVDA has to triple beat expectations for a rally into any new high zone. That's asking a lot.

author: @DominiqueGodefroy
comment: I invested in 2012 and have continued to accumulate shares during market downturns. I plan to hold until Q2 2026, at which point I will reassess the state of AI. At the same time, I am not an expert or analyst. In March 2023, I wondered about sovereign AI data center investments with NVIDIA. The recent $500 billion budget allocated in the USA is a confirmation. Many ‚Äúgurus‚Äù appear to be shortsighted and continue to dismiss NVIDIA. Those who do may miss out on a significant evolution in humanity altogether. Although I may not witness the complete products these changes bring, investments in profit-making or not contributing to a transformative shift for future generations is a good thing. I liken NVIDIA to Tyrell from Blade Runner, as each technological revolution brings unique value and disasters. Humanity's thinking is transitioning due to AI, which may lead to a more significant divide between those without economic access. All is shifting, but with reasoning and the pursuit of collective wisdom, it is less instinctive. A different jungle!

author: @GeoffDUB10
comment: Building the leading technology to power the future, and like Parkev said, almost flawlessly, these hiccups‚Äîtrue or not‚Äîhighlight Nvidia's dominance and innovation. They‚Äôre creating groundbreaking tech that every business wants, and their potential is vast. For shareholders, it‚Äôs debatable whether these slowdowns are better for long-term growth. Valuation and metrics aren‚Äôt out of whack; we just want Nvidia to go up 10% every month or double every two years. Oops, that‚Äôs Moore‚Äôs Law, my bad. As for the government slowing them down, it‚Äôs probably just a few weeks until the next administration steps in to take credit for saving the AI revolution‚Äîcue the next President claiming they or he invented it. And let‚Äôs be honest, how long until Jensen and Musk are in the White House with the roadmap to ‚Äòthe best ever‚Äô? In my humble opinion, buy or hold, or set it and forget it in fantasy companies, because we haven‚Äôt even hit the real Blackwell growth cycle yet. As long as Nvidia maintains leadership and continues innovating, their valuation may still be reasonable despite short-term fluctuations. The market can be volatile, but that doesn‚Äôt mean their overall value is out of line, especially considering AI and tech growth potential. Can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm saying all this‚Äîlast May I didn‚Äôt understand P/E, margins, or TAM. Professor Parkev‚Äôs videos and book helped me understand the fundamentals, and now I‚Äôm able to really dive into evaluating companies! (Plug for extra credit!) Opinion on Eli Lilly? I started a small position this morning on the dip?

author: @GeoEmertech
comment: The biggest risk with limiting the shipments of AI hardware to certain countries only is that countries that are excluded will go to the competition. This directly undermines NVidia's moat which isn't the hardware but the software. The competition will suddenly have more demand and a GUARANTEED market Nvidia can't access. So they'll be further incentivised to accelerate developing their software stack more until it is on par with NVidia's. In the short run, the US wins as whoever wants hardware will have to go through US cloud companies. But in the long run, US position as a global leader will be threatened by companies from countries which will have no such limitations.

comment:
Big techs will be doomed if they keep using PCB (printed circuit board for semiconductor packaging)
Furthermore there are obstacles for developing the HBM
 because of overheating. 
It means no further developments or
none of Paradigm shift.
The only way for the big techs such as NVIDIA, BROADCOM, AMD and so on to survive is to use glass substrate. 
Glass Substrate will dramatically reduce overheating and other constraints which PCB has had.
Absolics is the first company which makes the glass substrate mass productions.
korea has the most advanced technology, TGV, which is the major part  of glass substrate.

author: @bluemoon6559
comment: After GTC, the moat for Nvidia just got much much wider.  Nvidia is solving the tough issues with AI and Accelerated Computing.  No one else is talking about these things.  The competition is so behind that they are only focused on making a faster processor.  Nvidia revealed that the important considerations are energy usage and the TOC (total operating cost), not just faster processors.  You can have the fastest processor in the world, but if it burns 100MW to run it and requires humongous liquid nitrogen tanks to cool it, you will be out of business right away.  From the GTC, it shows Nvidia has figured out the sweet spot to operate their entire ecosystem and continues to optimize the hardware and software to squeeze out the most profit.  TOC is the bottom line and Nvidia is the only talking about it.

author: @ylegoff
comment:
"What competition??!! ..."   LOL. Stacy knows his stuff, unlike mile wide inch deep Dan and Guy permabear pundits.

A little over two years ago, in November 2022, *when NVDA was trading at $15* Dan Nathan and Guy Adami discussed Nvidia's earnings on CNBC's "Fast Money.": 

Guy Adami described Nvidia's quarter as "messy," noting a significant decline in net income compared to the previous year. He praised Nvidia as a great company with excellent management and products but considered the stock expensive. Despite the company's strengths, Adami believed the stock should be lower due to its valuation and the challenges it faced, such as supply chain issues and export bans.

Dan Nathan shared similar skepticism, stating he wouldn't want to be long on Nvidia at that time. He highlighted the company's gross margin miss and questioned whether Nvidia could achieve its guided gross margins for the fourth quarter. Nathan also noted that Nvidia had previously guided down its expectations twice during the summer, which suggested weak visibility for future performance.

Overall, both analysts were cautious about Nvidia's stock price at that time, emphasizing its high valuation and the challenges the company faced.

author: @bluemoon6559
comment: After GTC, the moat for Nvidia just got much much wider.  Nvidia is solving the tough issues with AI and Accelerated Computing.  No one else is talking about these things.  The competition is so behind that they are only focused on making a faster processor.  Nvidia revealed that the important considerations are energy usage and the TOC (total operating cost), not just faster processors.  You can have the fastest processor in the world, but if it burns 100MW to run it and requires humongous liquid nitrogen tanks to cool it, you will be out of business right away.  From the GTC, it shows Nvidia has figured out the sweet spot to operate their entire ecosystem and continues to optimize the hardware and software to squeeze out the most profit.  TOC is the bottom line and Nvidia is the only one talking about it in addition to all the innovations they have developed overcoming all the hardware and software issues.

author: @willieboykin8975
comment: Cary is actually telling you a buy point and a sell point as a trader. He's just more bearish than bullish based on the actual movement of the stock. If you're an investor (buy and hold) you should have already purchased more shares at 116-117. As a trader (profit taker) he's showing traders what the technicals are showing as a price range too short NVDA and what price range is a buy signal to go long on NVDA. Right now NVDA is staying below the 135-138 channel of resistance it briefly hit 136.50 today or the bottom end of the resistance channel then it broke up and closed below that level. It briefly hit 135.50 or so yesterday and again closed below that resistance zone. If NVDA closes below the zone tomorrow it's another sign of bearish momentum as institutional investors don't buy using emotions they buy using technicals (buy points) and if NVDA is able to rally through that 135-138 zone it's a signal for institutional buyers to start buying and if it rallys to 140 you can now be more confident in a sustained rally up to a new high going into earnings.

author: @B1GDAV301
comment:
The current spice melange is AI, and there is a vast dune of possibility.   

In the race for the world‚Äôs most valuable resource, AI time cycle is increasingly important.  

I think of an AI time cycle as the time it takes from the day you decide you‚Äôre going to build an AI, to the time that you release it for public use.   

$NVDA not only offers the best products and services for AI creation, they also offer the best AI time cycle on the planet. 

As an example, consider xAI and Grok3, announcement to release was 180 days. xAI used full Nvidia stacks (hardware, GPUs, software, networking and liquid cooling). xAI‚Äôs creation, Grok3, and the associated time cycle are unheard of, Grok3 is record breaking in intelligence, performance, and time cycle.  

Regarding Deepseek, they basically leached / stole knowledge to make their R1 smarter. That‚Äôs how they saved money.  

xAI is now moving from 200,000 $NVDA stacks towards 1,000,000 $NVDA stacks. I believe that at one million $NVDA stacks, xAI is going to create something the likes to which we‚Äôve never seen before. And at that level, it might just break Geoffrey Hinton‚Äôs model for distillation, meaning it might not be possible at that level. Sorry China.  

OBTW LLMs are not the end-all, be-all of AI. We are just getting started. We got things like neurosymbolic stuff, liquid neural networks, multi-modal, autonomous agents, self-improvement and replication, and other undiscovered creations, concentrations and quantities.

author: @shldngyl8724
comment:
In His ‚úùÔ∏è Kingdom. Jesus is KING‚Ä¶By 2030, NVIDIA stands as a tech titan whose path to prominence has been shaped by a blend of innovation, strategic risk-taking, and a relentless drive for excellence. However, its journey is entering a transformative phase, where sustaining its industry dominance requires balancing the dual forces of mastery and collaboration.

In the preceding years, NVIDIA will have solidified its role as a cornerstone of AI and high-performance computing. Its GPUs will remain the backbone of global AI infrastructure, powering everything from self-driving cars to breakthroughs in medicine, climate modeling, and advanced simulations. Yet, the pace of innovation in the tech world means the company can no longer rely solely on past successes. The once-clear lines between NVIDIA and its competitors will blur as new players, global economic shifts, and demands for sustainable tech solutions reshape the landscape.

Collaboration, a skill NVIDIA has honed but not yet perfected, will be the defining factor of its success or stagnation. By this point, the company will be deeply embedded in partnerships with governments, universities, and other industry leaders. These alliances will be crucial in advancing fields like quantum computing, renewable energy tech, and even AI ethics‚Äîareas where no single entity can tackle the challenges alone. However, working alongside such a diverse range of stakeholders will also bring challenges. Aligning priorities, managing intellectual property disputes, and maintaining a clear company vision in the midst of collaborative projects will test NVIDIA‚Äôs leadership.

Internally, the company will also face a cultural shift. The meticulous craftsmanship and laser-focused expertise that have brought it success so far will still be its core strength, but by 2030, this approach will require adaptation. Teams will need to embrace flexibility, breaking free from rigid hierarchies and encouraging more fluid, creative problem-solving processes. While NVIDIA has always been a company driven by brilliance and expertise, the key to its future lies in how well it fosters an environment of shared knowledge and synergy. The days of a single product or innovation carrying the company will be over‚Äîfuture growth will depend on holistic integration across its divisions.

On the global stage, NVIDIA‚Äôs reputation as a leader will still be strong, but it won‚Äôt be unchallenged. Countries and industries that previously relied heavily on its technology will begin fostering domestic alternatives, spurred by geopolitical tensions and a growing emphasis on tech sovereignty. This will place NVIDIA in the position of needing to innovate not just technologically but diplomatically‚Äîoffering unique value propositions that competitors cannot replicate while maintaining its role as a trusted global partner.

Finally, sustainability will become a central narrative for NVIDIA by 2030. Governments and consumers alike will demand energy-efficient solutions to offset the carbon footprint of high-performance computing. The company will need to spearhead advancements in green technology, incorporating recycled materials, renewable energy usage, and power-efficient architectures into its production pipelines. Success here will be both a technological and moral imperative, as public scrutiny of Big Tech‚Äôs environmental impact intensifies.

By 2030, NVIDIA‚Äôs journey will be a story of evolution. While its expertise and innovation remain unparalleled, its true challenge will be learning how to function as a more cohesive, collaborative, and adaptive organization. Success will require acknowledging the limits of individual mastery and embracing a broader vision of teamwork and shared purpose. If it can rise to this challenge, NVIDIA will not only maintain its relevance but also shape the next era of technological progress.

author: @plpl777-c7m
comment:
Big techs will be doomed if they keep using PCB (printed circuit board for semiconductor packaging)
Furthermore, there are obstacles to upgrading the HBM because of overheating. 
It means no further AI developments so long as there is none of Paradigm shift.
The only way for the big techs such as NVIDIA, BROADCOM, AMD, and so on to survive is to use glass substrate. 
Glass Substrate will dramatically solve the overheating and other constraints that PCB has had.
Absolics is the first company that makes the glass substrate mass productions.
korean company, philoptics,has the most advanced technology, TGV, which is the major part  of glass substrate.

author: @StevenLeBlanc-z9f
comment:
Cathie Wood IMO is more a hedge manager and one day she will be spectacularly right.  But not right now she is not what I am looking for in advice. 

To everyone saying XYZ stock is better, penny stock etc., that is not what investing is that is gambling.  You are trying to do what they call in horse racing "picking winners" and the pros do not try to 'pick winners' you will lose on average 67% of the time.  Can some do it?  Sure.  about 33%.  I wont take something with those odds but good luck to you.  And best wishes.

Investing for me is good quality companies that are #1 or #2 in their business segment with solid long term earnings and new product development track record over years with a forward PE that shows a value of at least 50% upside.

NVIDIA IMO is a 50-75%% bargain at 140 if it goes to $200 this year based on its forward PE of 30.  That is way cheaper than a lot of others out there and a good value IMO.

author: @DavidSaintloth
comment:
LoL, this is easy alpha to the focused investor. 

Correctly cooking the chip is the integrations fault 90% of the time. Not Nvidia's problem. All modern chips without active cooling will over heat in minutes. 

Integrators like Dell design cooling systems to minimize these heat related failures and their relative success at doing this is a greater reflection of the run time reliability than anything Nvidia has done in design. Extensive heat testing under variable clock speeds is partly how different chips are binned during yield evaluation. 

The dip was nothing but buying opportunity for me. I'd love some more tomorrow & Wednesday ahead of earnings likely surprising Wall St. To the upside. 

This is the perfect set up for a pop up to 150+

author: @TG4KHD
comment:
But is DeepSeek‚Äôs claim of low cost trustworthy? It‚Äôs highly doubtful. Based on my years of experience, I believe it is very likely part of a broader propaganda effort by Chinese authorities.

This company is a startup founded in Hangzhou in 2023, with a registered capital of just 10 million RMB. However, its background is shrouded in mystery. It‚Äôs not hard to imagine that there is state-backed support behind it. As such, whether the "low cost" promoted by China is genuine requires further scrutiny.

China has a well-documented history of fabrication. For example, the "Hanxin" chip, developed over 20 years ago, was touted by Chinese state media as a high-performance breakthrough for years, only to be exposed later as fraudulent. More recently, a 17-year-old vocational school student majoring in fashion design went viral as a "prodigy" after securing 12th place in Alibaba‚Äôs global math competition. However, it was later revealed that her math teacher had secretly helped her cheat.

It‚Äôs difficult for me to believe that in a country where everyone is required to study Xi Jinping's thoughts and speeches, and where freedom of thought and expression is nonexistent, enterprises could consistently innovate and lead the world in technology.

Some, including Elon Musk, have suggested that DeepSeek relies heavily on NVIDIA‚Äôs technology. If that‚Äôs the case, their costs would certainly not be low. It‚Äôs possible that Chinese authorities are quietly providing substantial subsidies behind the scenes.

Even if, hypothetically, China‚Äôs AI products truly offer "high quality at low cost," there remains a critical concern: users‚Äô data and secrets could easily end up in the hands of Chinese authorities. On this point alone, would multinational corporations dare to take the risk?

author: @TheExecutiveProducermaster
comment: Somebody is trying to stop the Nvidia blood bath because there is no good news for them. The hope was that someone would prove that that deepseek R1 was running on  5 or 3 nm chips and that would blow away the claim of improving GPU  through efficiency. Well, a lot of people are running DS and i personnally run kimi K1.5 on  intel 10 nm chips and the GPU is comparable to the superchips. only difference is in the power consumption, 10 nm is still a hungry beaver. I think NVIDIA better start lowering the price of their 5 & 3 nm because the  cheaper 10 nm route is wide open and i guarantee you that all opensource developers are optimizing their algorithm to free up more GPU for their development towards true AGI. In my opinion, NVIDIA margins will have to come down or else intel will be the choice for equipping  computers for datacenters until we reach true AGI.  A datacenter for a 5 or 3 nm could cost on average $500 M for a 10 nm $150M. However, the latter required access to electricity capacity at a very good cost. might want to get close to Hydro Quebec.

author: @ronjohnson2760
comment:
Nvidia just released its WORST generation of GPUs ever in the history of the company, which is impressive considering their last generation was considered their worst generation until now by leaps and bounds. Edward Snowdens remark on X hit the nail on the head. S tier prices for F tier value and performance uplift. The performance on these GPUs is so bad that in some cases the new GPUs lose to last generation GPUs of that same class in some cases and in others are virtually indistinguishable. This is on top of the blackwell launch being one of the worst GPU launches in the companies history unilaterally across all classes of the GPUs  that have been thus far released (5080 and 5090). They sold out to scalpers almost instantly but dont let that fool you, there were so few of these cards to begin with that this can be considered to be a manipulative and forced result designed to build fake hype and make these products look desirable. The truth is, nearly every single reputable tech influencer on youtube has been less than impressed and extremely negative on blackwell as a whole. 

The 3 big issues people have can be summarized as thus


- Worst generational performance uplift of any new generation of GPUs  Nvidia have ever released in the companies history.  
- Prices still very, very high
- The amount of VRAM on the cards is FAR less than it should be given the prices Nvidia is charging.  This is leading to a situation where you are made to pay a "no compromises" price for a card that WILL have significant issues because of the low VRAM amount. 

These issues and others are creating a situation that is pathetic, embarrassing for the company and WILL result in significant damage to their brand and image. 

Anyone saying that Nvidia is gonna do well is hard coping.

comment: It will take few years till there will be a serious competition to NVDA, till then everyone else are just hot air balloons. author: @phvaessen
comment:
By the time ASIC will have the same price/performance as Blackwell for inference, Nvidia will have Ruben in production.
The next growth phase for AI is software. Nvidia's business model could and will shift more (relative to current hardware revenue) to monetisation of software in the future. 
Nvidia platform already includes:
1. AI & Machine Learning Software 
2. Software Development & Frameworks  (for instance Omnivers toolkit)
3. GPU Virtualization & Cloud Computing
4. Robotics & Edge Computing for instanceAI-powered robotics development toolkit, or Software stack for Jetson AI edge computing.
5. Digital Twins & Graphics => Omniverse & Cosmos
6. Automotive & Autonomous Systems
-   NVIDIA DRIVE OS ‚Äì Autonomous vehicle operating system.
-   NVIDIA DRIVE Sim ‚Äì Simulation platform for AV development.
-  NVIDIA Clara ‚Äì AI-driven healthcare and medical imaging suite.

And  NIMs (NVIDIA Inference Microservices), which are part of NVIDIA AI Foundations and the NGC (NVIDIA GPU Cloud) ecosystem.

The market is again underestimating Nvidia: in 2016 they were "too expensive " as the graphic cards market for gamers was going to slowdown because the growth of the PC market were slowing down. At that time it was obvious that the data center market was the next growth market for accelerating computing. It's only with the announcement of ChatGPT that Wall Street finally understood the AI data center market created by Nvidia. And now Wall street beileves this is going to end ...

author: @GeoEmertech
comment: Actually Palantir doesn't sell software. They sell software services. They don't sell something like Windows or Adobe which are products that once built can be scaled from 1 client to millions easily. Their platforms are not plug-and-play. For every single client they have to take their platforms and integrate them with the databases, customize according to client needs, optimize, deploy and debug. It's still good that they invested in their platforms which reduce the costs for the client but it's akin to installing an ERP system like SAP. And like SAP has a ton of competition so will Palantir. Nvidia, on the other hands, has much more moat. Not completely without competition but much more moat. And the barrier-to-entry in Nvidia's market is much, much higher.

author: @Wattsepherson
comment:
The problem you have is Shorting.  Shorting was invented to allow big entities to manipulate the market. It's one of the most bitter and repulsive methods of gaining money and it's been a great way of dividing people.  You'll get people telling you a stock is terrible and that it's going "to tank" purely because they WANT it to fail. They've actually bet on it to fail and they don't care if it's doing well - they want it to fail, to go bankrupt.

Not only do you have the company's earnings reports to factor into investment but also the amount of shorting it suffers from because chances are the stock's going to yo-yo up and down forever and hardly ever go up much unless there's undeniable news that something is popular.

That's why, right now, you have a 50/50 like/dislikes on most stock because 50% of them want to find all the negatives and you have the optimists who still believe "good companies making a profit are worth investing in" scratching their heads trying to work out how a company can do well if there's a fight to want it to fail for shorting....

NVIDIA just beat all expectations and that was during a time where it's had to invest and slow down a little so they can build new factories to build more chips for demand and that's ignoring the physical robots AND trucks and all the other things they are prepping for the future.  There's been a small lapse because they're moving from consumer cards to the blackwell stuff. It's that simple and yet, even with all those good positive results it still, right now, "tanked" because people panic because shorters WANT everyone to panic.

It's the world we live in, full of negativity and people wanting to profit from failure and now, we spend more time worrying something's going to tank because it did well than tank because it's been done terrible for 6 years.

author: @FanaticalFuturist
comment:
We saw this coming SIX MONTHS ago at least so let‚Äôs dig in, and see what else is coming to ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù the USA tech bros:

1) The US banned the export of powerful Nvidia H100 and B200 AI training GPU‚Äôs - meaning China is trying to compete to develop AI models as good as the US‚Äôs with about 10% of the compute resources.
2) They took H100‚Äôs from gaming machines to bootstrap AI training clusters of around 10,000 GPU versus the US ‚ÄúAI Factories‚Äù like Musk‚Äôs of 300,000 GPU‚Äôs
3) They were the FIRST to figure out how to train Generative AI models across DISTRIBUTED data centers - a MAJOR breakthrough no one really reported on.
4) They discovered that the fourth ‚Äúrule‚Äùto AI scaling VERY POWERFUL AI models is TIME(!) - in this case AKA ‚ÄúChain of Thought Reasoning‚Äù giving Time for the AI‚Äôs to THINK about their answers - this is a game changer, it makes small models (EG: 50 Billion parameter models) BETTER than models 3-4x their size
5) You combine (2) and (4) alone and you have superior AI.

The US had SO MUCH compute resources and money they didn‚Äôt need to push the limits of innovation - the US forced China to out think them because they banned the sale of GPU‚Äôs (and now Huawei GPU‚Äôs look like they‚Äôre getting as good as Nvidia‚Äôs so that changes the game again!!!!!)

author: @michaelmurphy4829
comment: The minute someone talks about chips, it shows they do not understand what Nvidia is doing. Nvidia is providing a complete platform for data centers to massively increase their processing power with a CUDA software driven, stackable, parallel processing, power controlled system that no other company is close to matching. Cloud computing and storage, autonomous cars and taxis, AI data processing and every single software development application being worked on and brought to market must run on these data centers. Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Meta and many others will have in house uses for their own systems, but they will still run along networked data centers run by Nvidia equipment. This market will be growing for years to come. Nvidia will be offering new chips like their Rubin line that runs on way less power, making the switch to them free because the power savings will pay for the upgrades, further fueling their sales. Other companies are years behind even offering a cost effective alternative, and have no software system in place that can compete with Blackwell or Rubin. Stock will be $170 in another year with two or three more years of double digit growth. As of today, Nvidia is a cheaper stock than Starbucks. Your choice.

author: @randy74989
comment:
In a word: Blackwell and ASICS.

ANOTHER ANALYST LISTS THE FOLLOWING:
12/30/2024
"Wall Street‚Äôs AI darlings‚Äô risks are now well understood, i.e., the stock is no longer all rainbows and butterflies; reality has been priced in for now.
We spy teething overheating issues and higher competition with in-house ASIC as it comes to fruition, but we don't see these weighing on the current quarter.
In our opinion, investors should act now as Nvidia is poised to beat and raise guidance in 4QFY25, capitalizing on hyper-demand for Blackwell GPUs."
"What to do with the stock?
We cover Nvidia closely and see room for another trade next quarter as we expect the company to beat and outpace guidance on the Blackwell series ramp and hyper demand after a shaky last two quarters. It is shaky due to the product transition that began two quarters ago, and that weighed on margins and investor confidence alike, with management guiding for margins to be in the low-70% range due to the Blackwell ramp.

We're upgrading now because we see attractive entry points into the stock after it deflated a bit intraquarter. This was due to product transition concerns, particularly ones to do with overheating issues and the arrival of the in-house ASIC moment, which has gotten the market excited about other semis in the field, Broadcom and Marvell. The China investigation was the cherry on top that brought the stock down to more attractive levels and further confirmed our decision to jump back in."

author: @OG-Jakey
comment: That was an awful analysis at the end there. Jensen did not inspire confidence when talking about Asic at all imo. That other guy saying how just because your design a chip doesn't mean it's going to be built is total bs. Amazon, meta and Google have all built Asic. The issue with Asic right now I think, is that the models are still constantly changing so I think that does give Nvidia somewhat of a small safety net for now but in the future when the model changes have kind of plateaued is when Asic are really going to shine and take over. I also find it extremely annoying when Jenson makes a selling point about software, It's like bro, your ai is going to build software... your product is essentially going to make that selling point irrelevant when anyone can ask ai to build said software. Obv I'm thinking further ahead than the immediate and this isn't necessarily good for short term investing but it was quite painful to hear this salesman say next to nothing then hear those other 2 conclusions.

The issue with Asic right now I think, is that the models are still constantly changing so I think that does give Nvidia somewhat of a small safety net for now but in the future when the model changes have kind of plateaued is when Asic are really going to shine and take over. I also find it extremely annoying when Jenson makes a selling point about software, It's like bro, your ai is going to build software... your product is essentially going to make that selling point irrelevant when anyone can ask ai to build said software. author: @paulschaaf8880
comment: I loved your software comparison example and I think that really drives home a major reason for Nvidia's dominance even if a competitor had a faster chip.  If it's 10x easier to get your software to work on Nvidia, most companies are going to stick with Nvidia.  I think we're basically looking at a market that's split into 2 segments.  There's the lion's share of the market dominated by Nvidia and then there's a small segment of the market split between everyone else in the (not Nvidia) market.  The not Nvidia market is only there so companies can plausibly tell Nvidia hey, we don't HAVE to use your chips, so please limit your mark up to 1,000% instead of 10,000%...  Most of the not Nvidia players are only using their chips internally with AMD and Intel being the main companies trying to actually sell their chips externally and AMD being the only one really doing so with any real success.

author: @Mxyzptlk30
comment:
If you major in Computer Engineering (a mix of Comp Science and Electrical Engineering), you get to touch on a lot of how the Mag 7 works.  Whether it's for ASIC or chip design, or writing software and creating AI models or maintaining data centers, or even working on power electronics, computer engineering is where it's at.  And you get to learn how to create and program all sorts of cool gadgets that you can think of from that knowledge.  It also puts you in a position of understanding how companies are run and why they'll be successful: from Apple's intro of the App Store and it's developer ecosystem to opensource AI models, like Meta's Llama.

TSLA is great, but NVDA has had a significantly better return over the years than TSLA.  Past performance is no guarantee of future results, but based on where AI is going, I'd say NVDA is still in a better position than TSLA, even if Tesla solves FSD.  That being said, I own both TSLA and NVDA, cuz I'm a computer geek and they're both great companies.

author: @markedgar5678
comment: Jose, - Question: Even if OpenAI gets a decent chip designed, off the tape and starting to produce.  How much production capacity does TSMC have for higher 2-3nm type chips in the next 1-4 years? I was under the impression that NVDIA is "blocking out" ANY available manufacturing capacity that becomes availabe in the TSMC schedule. And NVIDIA gets a premium for its GPUs, and to some NEWS is paying a slight premium to TSMC.  And TSMC likes that premium because NVIDIA has a premium. So why would TSMC undercut it‚Äôs *BEST* customers bottom line? Meaning, unless TSMC is playing the three-to-ten year insurance strategy.  Why would they get anywhere near mass production of a competing chip, a chip that SHOULD be years behind NVIDIA lineage?  ‚Äî Unless it is a next year or two play by OpenAI to get a better price on Rubin and then Rubin Ultra?  Thoughts?

author: @ashman0071
comment: Well I can tell you, bought my son a HP computer 12 years ago and in less than 2 years the thing 'broke' - turned out the GPU failed - I was pissed.  But when it turned out the GPU was made by a company (Nvidia) that had basically cornered the market  - although I wasn't thrilled about purchasing something that appeared unreliable - I had to.  So I bought a lot of their stock.  Turns out the replacement GPU has been working now since.   Another 'story'- I  had a Toto toilet that the flapper valve started leaking about 16 years ago.  After work I went to Home Depot, Lows one day and Ace Hardware and another Mom and Pop Hardware store another day.  The stores were unorganized, the employees couldn't help me and they didn't have an OEM replacement.  So I went to Amazon, input the part number from the Toto Toilet flapper and by the time I got home the next day it was on my door step .....  it's all 'right in front of your face' as my Dad would say.   Foreign markets you don't interact with - just like small caps. Don't buy them - Value investing is 'almost' dead with inflation that doesn't account for Food and Energy - wtf?  The market since about 2015 has been driven by about 12 stocks that have gone up about 10 times in value.  Individual Money managers 'rarely' beat simple index funds - arithmetically they can't - there a research papers on this - find them. Buy Gold ETF's have you seen how Gold has been doing the last 3 years ?

comment: This is why people with no experience in politics shouldn't pretend to understand what is going on. If you pay any attention to modern or historical politics you'd know that we used to run on tariffs instead of an income tax but in the 1920s prior to the great depression we switched to running on taxes. This is simply an inversion of this choice and we've already been warned that there will be a temporary period where we'll suffer from the tariffs and that it would take a few months before we see economic stability. Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency on the crypto market it's not a stock it doesn't act like a stock. Its value doesn't rise and fall the same way that a stock falls. Nvidia's stock has been slowly going down since December and hasn't been able to rebound with lackluster announcements in their GPU line up. author: @matrix170982
comment:
Using NVDA as an example, as a software developer, I cannot find any other company that can compete with NVDA both in h/w and s/w. Look at Intel and AMD. Intel is struggling to compete with AMD in x86 and no market share in GPU nor Mobile Devices. AMD also try to stay ahead with Intel in x86 and only allocate relatively small R/D in GPU market to just try to beat NVDA in h/w, AMD do not have any solution with the s/w side. As for NVDA, they laser focus in building great h/w with great s/w and thus has successfully walled garden their Data Center solutions, just like Apple when Steve Jobs introduce the iPhone (great h/w and great s/w too).

NVDA is a lot like Apple when they first introducing iPhone and attract so many developer to build ecosystem around iPhone, until Google come in and try to compete with Apple both in h/w and s/w, but only manage to beat Apple in s/w side, not h/w side.

My own observation: NVDA will be a market leader in Data Center side just like Apple with iPhone in Consumer side for about 3 more years, judging from other MAG-7 Capex planning.
NVDA will get a lot of revenues from Data Center market until the market is exhausted in USA, and then if China market opened again, I'm sure that will be another boost for NVDA.

author: @ashman0071
comment: Well I can tell you, bought my son a HP computer 12 years ago and in less than 2 years the thing 'broke' - turned out the GPU failed - I was pissed.  But when it turned out the GPU was made by a company (Nvidia) that had basically cornered the market  - although I wasn't thrilled about purchasing something that appeared unreliable - I had to.  So I bought a lot of their stock.  Turns out the replacement GPU has been working now since.   Another 'story'- I  had a Toto toilet that the flapper valve started leaking about 16 years ago.  After work I went to Home Depot, Lows one day and Ace Hardware and another Mom and Pop Hardware store another day.  The stores were unorganized, the employees couldn't help me and they didn't have an OEM replacement.  So I went to Amazon, input the part number from the Toto Toilet flapper and by the time I got home the next day it was on my door step .....  it's all 'right in front of your face' as my Dad would say.   Foreign markets you don't interact with - just like small caps. Don't buy them - Value investing is 'almost' dead with inflation that doesn't account for Food and Energy - wtf?  The market since about 2015 has been driven by about 12 stocks that have gone up about 10 times in value.  Individual Money managers 'rarely' beat simple index funds - arithmetically they can't - there a research papers on this - find them. Buy Gold ETF's have you seen how Gold has been doing the last 3 years ?

author: @brotherthegreat3617
comment:
The problem is that the Chinese government subsidizes the technology produced in China which allows them to implement it into the market faster than US tech, like bullet trains and better luxury vehicles than in the US. As a result, if the US government does not help pay for the implementation of new technologies, then China will eventually create a technology gap wide enough that allows them to take all of our foreign and potential foreign customers therefore threatening our country as a global superpower. Suggesting we are currently in a cold war not on military might but on technological innovation and implementation.

Edit: This is just a hypothesis and I welcome feedback for or against what I said. However, this does not seem threatening to NVIDIA in the short term or to the US, but we need to stop and think about how that difference between countries could affect the US in the long term.

author: @DeltaHouseStudios
comment: Stock market shares do not reflect a company‚Äôs actual income or value. If you buy a truck from a dealership for $100k and sell it for $50k, the dealership didn‚Äôt lose $50kü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è conversely, if you buy a truck from a dealer for $20k and sell it for $100k, the original dealership didn‚Äôt earn $80k. Nvidia‚Äôs total equity is $42 billion. So no they didn‚Äôt lose $600 billion dollars because the value of their shares went down in the stock market. Stock market shares are tiny percentages of ownership. Buying and selling those tiny percentages doesn‚Äôt send money to the company.

author: @mikerodent3164
comment: Interesting idea about the effect of such massive proportion of passive tracking. It also occurs to me that exactly that might in fact slow down the correction when the "AI"-nonsense bubble starts to burst. Ordinarily, active investors, including institutions, might be able to recognise a correction when it starts, and animal spirits cause a pile-out. But if a huge chunk of all investment assets (50%+ as stated here) is just a "lump" which automatically readjusts, its inertia may well lead active investors to do a double-take: they think it's time to pile out ... and then not much happens, ... so they come back in. In other words, the sheer weight of passive leads to a self-fulfilling prophecy situation. And how does that end? My guess would be: stodge. Nvidia, and all the other nonsense-stocks, just kind of grind to a halt, in terms of total return. Already yes, clever people like Monsieur Buffett have concluded that the P/E on "AI"-nonsense is completely useless. Eventually we just enter territory where people are losing money (because of inflation) by sitting on turgid Nvidia-like stock. But that would also have implications for the (rational) hoarders: BRK can only start buying again when buying opportunities arise: prices have to drop first. Interesting times.

author: @theDudemanok
comment:
This is a great conversation.  A few counter-arguments;

1. Everyday someone holds a stock, they choose to buy that stock. If Granny Smith company stock had risen by 50, and its inclusion on the S&P was not based on fundamentals,  an insider could have sold. 

2. In 1930, American Sugar was the biggest company on the S&P 500. Exxon was the biggest in 2007. The index will survive replacements. It always has‚ÄîNvidia was-number-i-don't-know-what in 2015.

3. Security selection isn't the reason major investors are skeptical of the market; it is the macro picture. Replacing an equity ETF for another investment that has an active strategy or an asset class that has market risk doesn't reduce your overall risk.

author: @MyLifeOfficial
comment:
Someone said - "How can I buy more, if I've already spent my money and bought?"

Well then you watch it all crash, and your portfolio reduces by around 30% or more when it happens. You watch other people say "I'm buying more! This is an opportunity!", and when you look at their screenshots of how much more they're buying, you see that they've bought another $68.90 worth in NVDIA fractional shares, and $87.54 worth fractional shares in PLTR, rather than people buying more with hundreds if not thousands of dollars, and you realise that everyone's an idiot, and the party is about to end for a while, and now we have to deal with the hangover...CNBC brings in their top contributor Tom Lee on set, and he tries to explain the crash, and how this is only temporary, and telling everyone to buy as it's a buying opportunity, but no one has any money to buy... Why? Because Wall Street has the money now, the very money that you spent to buy the stock when everyone was telling you that it was a buying opportunity, but ironically, even Wall Street doesn't have the money to buy either, because they took it all as their bonuses and spent it on first class flights, fancy hotels and holidays...so the crash happens and no one has any money to buy the dip anymore, and so we see the dip's dip, and the dippity dip's dip...all the way until those who actually have the real money step in and start to buy.

author: @mytrigger5613
comment: We're in a state of limbo right now. Buying, like this guy has, figuring that it will come back at some point is fine if you have millions all over the place and you just want to get in at what appears to be a bargain entry. For me, I'm 51 and i have 55k in the market. I'm looking at 2022 where the dip we had this week came and bounced slightly then down with another hopeful bounce, and this repeated to a 25% market loss over i think a 6 or 9 month bear market …ìefore bouncing a double bounce off the bottom before rip roaring to where we are at now. I remember when my stocks approached break even and my gains were washed up and i made the decision to accept where i was at, not knowing it it was just a pull back yet and i decided to sell down to 4 stocks, so that i narrowed my focus but also this way i would have cash to buy in if this market kept going lower. For me this was a good move and turned out to be, rather than watch 100% of my portfolio dip 25% i now had 50% declining 25% while my cash was able to buy into the 4 stocks i was holding bringing down my overall entry. So I'm looking at this market right now and thinking the same strategy. Luckily my stocks haven't been adversely affected. I don't have any tesla or palentir or nvidia, but in 2022 i had nvidia, uber, Spotify and tradedesk. If you only held 4 stocks now and had half your portfolio in cash to buy down your positions what 4 would they be? Or what sectors would they be in? Will Ai bounce and continue or are you playing it safe and avoiding that? Consumer staples? At least one i think Health care? Meh. Energy? What kind? Are you buying tesla or does this time feel different and not in a good way? I'm just encouraging anyone who reads this to narrow your focus, but commit to some cash even if you have to take some losses. It sucks after watching the profits you squandered, you're not alone, but you'll be happy you made the decision when it dips another 10%or more particularly if it isn't a strong candidate to rally back like a walmart would be.

author: @garyk.nedrow8302
comment: The financial media is missing the mark on NVDA.  The stock has sold off since its last earnings announcement because it is fairly valued for now and the fast  money guys (FMG) are dumping shares of NVDA to chase the upward trend in financial and military defense stocks.  It is a simple rotation of speculators out of NVDA.  The speculative hysteria is over, but the reality remains that NVDA itself is a buy.  It made its 3rd quarter numbers and will continue to grow, at a slightly less meteoric pace, for the foreseeable future.  It is very likely, given its enormous cash position, that NVDA will soon become a much larger company (via acquisition or organic growth in new product lines) and generate even greater profits.  The tech revolution will be powered by NVDA for years to come.

author: @mikebuchanan7610
comment:
Not to derail, but Trump's argument about the Canadian border stretches the truth to put it mildly, and is not likely to have the result he intended. He used the IEEPA to get around his own trade agreement in order to impose tariffs, but less than 1% of illegals and fentanyl come from Canada. What emergency? The result of this is that Canadians have concluded that they cannot trust Trump, and that means not trusting America for at least the next four years. Hard to negotiate with people who do not trust you. He is, however, accomplishing something once thought to be impossible. Canada is now looking to remove provincial trade barriers. It is estimated that these barriers add up to the equivalent of a 21% tariff, and removing them will add roughly $200B to the economy. Canada is also looking to diversify trade, which may mean lost opportunity for the US in the future, and diminished influence, as the end goal would be to get into a position where this kind of leverage cannot be used again. Rather than making it the 51st state, he's making it more nationalistic.

I agree that this is largely unrelated, and thus it is a buying opportunity. I already have a large position in Nvidia, but added leaps at 100 and 105.

author: @wahlin89
comment:
Thanks for a great point of View. I'd love for to hear your opinion of Sivers semiconductors. 

Sivers Semiconductors ‚Äì The Backbone of AI Connectivity
As AI scales, Nvidia‚Äôs GPUs demand high-speed, low-latency data transfer‚Äîand that‚Äôs where Sivers comes in. Their silicon photonics and mmWave solutions enable ultra-fast optical interconnects for AI data centers, making them a critical supplier in the AI infrastructure boom.

With a ‚Äúpicks and shovels‚Äù position in the AI race and potential ties to Nvidia‚Äôs growing ecosystem, Sivers is poised for exponential growth as demand for high-bandwidth connectivity surges.

That's my opinion and finding but I would like to hear what the professionals think. ü§î

author: @andikasapi9563
comment:
‚ÄúI hope Nvidia loses more money because they have done the worst marketing ever and provided almost no product. There has been a huge lack of stock, consequently disappointing all customers. What was the point of trying to get people hyped for the 50-series if there are no GPUs? I saw massive queues at the shops, with people camping overnight like Bear Grylls, wrapped in blankets just to survive the night.

It was the worst launch day I have ever experienced. I was personally disgusted to see stock issues making a comeback, reminiscent of post-WWII Eastern European communism. Instead of planning ahead to prevent these issues, they blamed the Chinese New Year‚Äîjust another excuse. We‚Äôre talking about a massive engineering company, yet their CEO, in his glittering new Las Vegas jacket, was busy showing off extreme graphics performance while customers struggled to get their hands on the product.

Something seems a little off to me. It feels like old-school dictator propaganda‚Äîhyping up a product with barely any stock, forcing desperate people to camp overnight just to get a tiny piece of the ridiculously rationed supply.‚Äù

author: @simply-tom
comment: In all logic, you should either HOLD with what you already have and don't get into all the hype. If you want to buy more or those that want to get in on NVDA, now is the time to buy when they're low. Yes, this is scary news but Nvidia has a major hold on technology and still the leader in chip development and AI. It is hard to predict what will happen when we don't know all the facts or any inside info. The main issue is the cost of developing AI and Deepseek is doing it for significantly lower price and just as powerful. Or is it? There needs to be more analysis on Deepseek before we can jump to any solid conclusions. Like what they are actually using, and just how much more powerful is their AI. If it turns out to be inferior to Nvidia AI, now we know. If its vice versa, then this is an issue for Nvidia. For now, I still feel NVDA will get over this hump. More so if they can control their spending for now. Like Parkev mentioned, this may be an over reaction to the news.

author: @bluestarcesium
comment: There are many people, who brought Nvidia on margins, and the stock watchers and options traders know when a stock is topping out, then, they sell the stock. Then, the short sellers start selling the stock short. This causes there to be more sellers than buyers, and the stock falls faster. Then, margin calls are made, which causes many more shares to hit the market. Soon, all the day traders are out, the people on margin are out, and the stock starts to bottom ten to fifteen percent below it‚Äôs high. The shares begin a bottoming process of consolidation, where large mutual funds, investors, and traders begin to accumulate some shares.
